inlineContent.text: provides an interface for writing a byte stream either synchronously or asynchronously. You can create streams that write bytes to a block of memory, a file, or a generic socket. All streams need to be opened, using
for reading byte streams, and for the functions, such as
is “toll-free bridged” with its Cocoa Foundation counterpart,
. This means that the Core Foundation type is interchangeable in function or method calls with the bridged Foundation object. Therefore, in a method where you see an
parameter, you can pass in a
, and in a function where you see a
parameter, you can pass in an
instance. Note, however, that you may have either a delegate or callbacks but not both. See
for more information on toll-free bridging.

abstract.text: Returns the error status of a stream.
Sets the value of a property for a stream.
Schedules a stream into a run loop.
Returns the error associated with a stream.
Creates a writable stream for a fixed-size block of memory.
Creates a writable stream for a file.
Returns the type identifier of all CFWriteStream objects.
Assigns a client to a stream, which receives callbacks when certain events occur.
Writes data to a writable stream.
Returns whether a writable stream can accept new data without blocking.
Creates a writable stream for a growable block of memory.
Returns the value of a property for a stream.
Closes a writable stream.
Returns the current state of a stream.
Removes a stream from a particular run loop.
Opens a stream for writing.
The CFFileDescriptor provides an opaque type to monitor file descriptors for read and write activity via CFRunLoop.

CFStringTokenizer allows you to tokenize strings into words, sentences or paragraphs in a language-neutral way. It supports languages such as Japanese and Chinese that do not delimit words by spaces, as well as de-compounding German compounds. You can obtain Latin transcription for tokens. It also provides language identification API.
A reference to a writable stream object.
Callback invoked when certain types of activity takes place on a writable stream.
